Scheme 1 Expected products of (R)-Carvone Epoxidation. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Epoxidation of (R)-carvone with H2O2 catalyzed by Ga(NO3)3 and blank test (without catalyst). (A) Conversion of (R)-carvone. Accumulation of endocyclic epoxide (B) and exocyclic epoxide (C). Conditions: (R)-carvone, 1 M; Ga(NO3)3, 2 × 10−2 M (except blank test curve); H2O2, 4 M; ethyl acetate up to 5 mL; 80 °C. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone using different pyridine derivatives as cooperating ligands. (A) Conversion of (R)-carvone. Accumulation of endocyclic (B) and exocyclic (C) epoxide. Conditions: (R)-carvone, 1 M; Ga(NO3)3, 2 × 10−2 M; cooperating ligand, 8 × 10−2 M; H2O2, 4 M; ethyl acetate up to 5 mL; 80 °C. In this work, the catalytic epoxidation of (R)-carvone by the Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 system was studied alongside the metal-ligand cooperation by exploring 17 different ligands. It was observed that the acidic ligands such as acetic acid mostly favor the epoxidation of the endocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (22% yield, 1 h), while nitrogen heterocycles direct the epoxidation to the exocyclic double bond, especially the ones that are unsubstituted or have electron-donating groups, such as pyrazine (28% yield, 5 h), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (28% yield, 8 h), and 1-methyimidazole (43% yield, 8 h). Pyrazinecaboxylic acid favored the epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond (25%, 3 h). EPR analysis of both Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 and Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 systems indicates the presence of hydroxyl radicals in the reaction medium, although these do not determine the epoxidation rate that is likely regulated by the interaction of Ga-peroxo complexes with (R)-carvone. This study contributes to widening the application of the cooperating ligand concept in molecular catalysis toward further development of more selective and efficient epoxidation reactions catalyzed by non-transition metal centers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic epoxidation (R)-carvone Homogeneous catalysis Gallium nitrate Hydrogen peroxide Metal-ligand cooperation 1 Introduction Epoxides are building blocks widely used to produce compounds with high commercial relevance [1]. Traditionally, epoxides are obtained via the epoxidation of olefins catalyzed by transition metal-based catalysts. Although these catalysts are efficient in many cases, most of them are not suitable for large-scale processes owing to high cost and catalyst design requirements. To minimize this problem, various promising routes have been described for the epoxidation of olefins using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant and non-transition metal oxides (aluminum [2–9], gallium [10–15], or calcium [16]) as catalysts or promoters). Simple salts of aluminum(III) and gallium(III) in solution have been showed as efficient catalysts for the epoxidation of olefins with hydrogen peroxide [17–19]. According to Novikov et al. [20], the epoxidation of olefins by [M(H2O)n]3+/H2O2 (M = Ga, In, Y, and La) can take place via a non-radical pathway by hydroperoxide species (HOO−), with a mechanism involving a replacement of water ligand in [M(H2O)n]3+ by H2O2. The deprotonation of coordinated H2O2 resulted in a hydroperoxo [M(H2O)n-1(OOH)]2+ complex (the active form of the catalyst). Finally, a hydroxy‑epoxide adduct is formed through a transition state between [M(H2O)n-1(OOH)]2+ and the olefin substrate, thus allowing an oxygen transfer of HOO− to the olefin. Metal-ligand cooperation (MLC) has become an important concept in homogeneous catalysis with metal complexes. Khusnutdinova and Milstein reviewed this concept [21] highlighting two types of MLC. In one of them, there is a chemical modification of both metal and ligand during a bond activation step. In the other one, there is an instant modification of the first coordination sphere involving the cooperating ligand, although the ligand's reactive site might not be directly connected to the metal center (this can occur via a formation of tautomers) [21]. Carvone (C10H14O) is an important natural product for the synthesis of different chiral compounds, including other naturally occurring molecules [22,23]. Carvone epoxides are used as raw materials to produce pharmaceuticals [24–26]. The presence of two double bonds in carvone (exocyclic and endocyclic C=C bonds), enables the formation of different epoxides (Scheme 1 ) and makes challenging the control of selectivity. A better understanding of reactivities and modes of action of the oxidative species toward different C=C bonds is a key to increasing the reaction selectivity [27]. Earlier, we obtained interesting results on alkene epoxidation catalyzed by a soluble gallium salt upon the addition of 2-pyrazinecarboxylic acid (PCA). This process led to a higher reaction rate and product yield in all the reactions tested, and an interesting behavior in the selectivity on the epoxidation of carvone was noticed [18]. However, considering only those preliminary results, the real role of the PCA in the system was unclear. Besides, there were doubts on the actual effect of the carboxylic and pyrazine functional groups on PCA, including what fragment of the molecule would be responsible for the selectivity on the endocyclic and exocyclic double bond. Finally, new experiments were necessary to confirm the participation of hydroxyl radicals in the oxidation or even propose Ga-peroxo complex as active species. In 2016, we also believed that PCA favored the formation of external epoxide, improving the generation of hydroxyl radicals, that would be the main species responsible for the attack at the external double bond [18]. Inspired by those intriguing preliminary results [18], we proposed here a more complete study, expanding the scope to other similar cooperative ligands, to find a correlation between the ligand structure and catalytic-activity/selectivity of (R)-carvone epoxidation by Ga(NO3)3/H2O2. Hence, we describe herein a detailed study on the homogeneous Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone with hydrogen peroxide, in the presence of PCA and 16 other different cooperating ligands comprising of pyridine, bipyridine, pyrazine, and imidazole derivatives, as well as different acids. To improve the knowledge on the reaction mechanism, the influence of various reaction parameters was investigated, including kinetic, EPR, and oxidant efficiency studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Epoxidation reactions The reactions were carried out in a thermostatic reactor at 80 °C. Concentrations of reagents were 1 M of (R)-carvone, 4 M of H2O2 (70% in H2O), 0.02 M of Ga(NO3)3·9H2O, and when used, 0.08 M of cooperating ligand; ethyl acetate was added as a solvent up to 5 mL. Nitromethane was used as an internal standard for monitoring the reaction progress by gas chromatography (GC). The GC analyzes were conducted on a Shimadzu GC-2010 chromatograph equipped with a SGE BP-20 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25  μ m) and a FID detector, using N2 as carrier gas. For characterization of unidentified compounds, GC-MS analyzes were performed on a Shimadzu QP2010 GC-MS equipped with a polar SOLGEL-Wax column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm), an electron impact ionization source, and a simple quadrupole analyzer. 2.2 Determination of the amount of O2 released via the decomposition of H2O2 A 50 mL burette was attached by the end to a settling funnel through a hose. The two pieces were used upright and filled with water to form communicating vessels. Through a glass tube, the reactor was connected to the burette by the upper end, so that the volume of O2 released by the reaction was measured. For the measurement, it was necessary to equalize internal pressure with atmospheric pressure, regulating the position of the separation funnel, as shown in Fig. S1 (Supplementary material). 2.3 Purification of products by column chromatography Purifications by column chromatography were performed using silica gel 60 (0.063–0.200) from Merck® as stationary phase and a mixture of hexane, ethyl acetate, and triethylamine (ratio of 1:8.6:0.4) as eluent. The purification was monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC), which was performed using Sigma-Aldrich® silica gel plates. 2.4 Characterization of products by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) The solution 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained on a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer (Varian Inc.), using deuterated benzene as solvent. The chemical shifts (δ) are relative to tetramethylsilane (TMS), used as the internal standard. 2.5 Kinetic studies by electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) The EPR spectra were obtained using a Bruker spectrometer, model EMX, operating in the band X (ν = 9.5 GHz) with the power of 20 mW, using quartz tubes, flat cell. The modulation amplitude was adjusted to 5 G for the samples in water. The solutions containing the samples were analyzed at a previously calibrated frequency (g = 2.0036). For the analysis, an aliquot of the reaction medium was collected and diluted tenfold in ethyl acetate, DMPO-stained (80 mM; DMPO = 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide), and readily analyzed by EPR at room temperature. TEMPOL (4‑hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidyloxy) solution (36.0 μM) was used as the standard for quantification of the captured radicals [28,29]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 (R)-carvone epoxidation The epoxidation of (R)-carvone was performed in the absence and presence of Ga(NO3)3 catalyst. Conversion of (R)-carvone and accumulation of epoxides are shown in Fig. 1 . Both reactions form predominantly diastereomer mixtures of epoxides B and C (Scheme 1). It should be noted that diepoxide (D), diol, and other products from parallel reactions such as cyclization and polymerization were not detected by GC. A typical chromatogram of the reaction mixture of (R)-carvone epoxidation is presented in Fig. S2. The catalytic system is more active for the epoxidation of the endocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (Fig. 1B), resulting in a maximum yield of 15% after 30 min. In the absence of Ga(NO3)3, the epoxidation does not reveal a significant accumulation of epoxides with the conversion of 30% after 5 h, whereas the catalytic system presented an 80% conversion (Fig. 1A). The formation of endocyclic and exocyclic epoxides was confirmed by GC-MS (Fig. S3). 3.1.1 Pyridine based cooperating ligands The influence of pyridine derivatives on the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone was studied with pyridine, 3-pyridinecarbonitrile, 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP), and 4-methylpyridine. In general, the addition of such cooperating ligands favors the selective epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (Fig. 2 C). The highest conversion (80%) was obtained when using 3-pyridinecarbonitrile ligand, followed by 40–50% conversion in the presence of other pyridine derivatives. The best yield for the exocyclic epoxide was obtained with DMAP (25% after 5 h), while with 4-methylpyridine and pyridine the highest yields were 17% and 20%, respectively, both after 5 h (Fig. 2C). An additional test carried out with DMAP ligand by increasing the reaction time led to the highest yield of the exocyclic epoxide, 28% after 8 h. In contrast, 3-pyridinecarbonitrile presented the same performance as the reaction in the absence of ligands, with 5% yield after 8 h. The presence of electron-donating groups (-CH3 and -N(CH3)2) in the structures of DMAP and 4-methylpyridine improves the reaction yield and increases the initial rate of exocyclic epoxide formation when compared with the cooperating ligand containing an electron-withdrawing group (-CN), which led to only 5% product yield (Fig. 2C). The catalytic systems containing pyridine derivatives showed similar results for the endocyclic epoxide with yields below 7%. Hence, all pyridine derivatives inhibit the endocyclic epoxide formation in comparison to the system in the absence of any ligand (yield of 15%). 3.1.2 Bipyridine based cooperating ligands The effect of bipyridine based cooperating ligands (i.e., 2,2′-bipyridine, 4,4′-bipyridine, and 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid) was investigated in the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone. As observed for simpler pyridine derivatives, bipyridines also favor the selective epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (Fig. 3 C). The highest conversion (95%) was obtained when using 2,2′-bipyridine, followed by 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (85%) and 4,4′-bipyridine (75%) (Fig. 3A). It can be noticed that for the exocyclic epoxide (Fig. 3C), the use of 2,2′-bipyridine (bidentate chelating ligand) led to an increased product formation rate during the first hour of the reaction, affording 14% of yield. For 4,4′-bipyridine, a gradual accumulation of the exocyclic epoxide product was observed, reaching 13% yield after 5 h. The nitrogen basicity seems to play an important role in promoting the exocyclic epoxide formation, given a lower product yield (6% after 8 h) in the reaction using 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-carboxylic acid as a cooperating ligand (Fig. 3C). Regarding the endocyclic epoxide formation (Fig. 3B), the use of 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-carboxylic acid results in a 13% yield after 3 h, which is slightly lower if compared to the reaction without any cooperating ligand. In the case of 2,2′-bipyridine and 4,4′-bipyridine, the yields of the endocyclic epoxide are below 5%. 3.1.3 Pyrazine based cooperating ligands The presence of pyrazine derivatives, such as 2-methylpyrazine, pyrazine-2- carboxylic acid (PCA), 5-methyl-pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid (CH3-PCA), and pyrazine as cooperating ligands, favored the selective epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (Fig. 4 C). The highest conversion (95%) was observed when using PCA ligand, followed by 85% conversion for the other pyrazine derivatives. The most expressive yields of the exocyclic epoxide were obtained in the presence of PCA and pyrazine, namely 25% (after 3 h) and 28% (after 5 h), respectively (Fig. 4C). The yields obtained with CH3-PCA and 2-methyl-pyrazine were lower than 15% after 5 h. An additional study was carried out with pyrazine by adding, after 5 h of reaction, a fresh portion of 1 M H2O2. As a result, the yield of the exocyclic epoxide further increased from 28 to 34%. For the epoxidation reactions in the presence of pyrazine-based ligands, the yields of endocyclic epoxide were lower compared to the reaction in the absence of added ligand (15% yield after 30 min) (Fig. 4B). Table 1 presents a comparison between the proportion of endocyclic and exocyclic epoxides yields [Endo – Exoc], in the presence of pyrazine derivatives as cooperating ligands. In the absence of cooperating ligand, the proportion of [Endo – Exoc) was almost constant for different reaction times, nearly [15–2%] (Ent 1). However, when pyrazine derivatives were added, a noticeable change in selectivity over time was observed. With PCA, the proportion [Endo – Exoc] was totally inverted, after longer reaction time, going from [10–6%] after 0.5 h to [2–25%] with 3 h (Ent. 2). A similar feature was also observed with the addition of pyrazine as a cooperating ligand, in which the [Endo – Exoc] epoxide yields changed from [5–4%] to [5–25%] (Ent. 3). In contrast, the reactions with methyl-pyrazine and methyl-PCA the alteration in the yields was less pronounced, with the proportion [Endo – Exoc] changing from [5–3%] to [5–12%] (Ent. 4) and from [11–3%] to [6–10%] (Ent. 5), respectively. The electron-donating inductive effect and the steric hindrance of the methyl substituent may have a negative influence on the exocyclic epoxide formation. 3.1.4 Imidazole based cooperating ligands It was observed that the addition of imidazole derivatives (imidazole, 1-methylimidazole (Met-Imida), or 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMIzoleBF4)) favors the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone (Fig. 5 C). After 5 h, all reactions run in the presence of imidazole ligands reached conversions above 50% (Fig. 5A). Taking into consideration the formation of the exocyclic epoxide, 1-methylimidazole was the best cooperating ligand, giving a maximum yield of 32% after 5 h, followed by imidazole (30% yield). In contrast, the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation in the absence of cooperating ligand leads less than 5% yield (Fig. 5C). An additional study was carried out by increasing the reaction time in the system containing 1-methylimidazole, resulting in a further increased yield of the exocyclic epoxide product (43% after 8 h, Fig. 5C). The reaction mixture from this catalytic system was collected and submitted to the purification process. As a result of this approach, 0.341 g of exocyclic epoxide were isolated, reaching 41% yield after 8 h of the reaction, which is close to the results observed in the quantitative analysis by GC (43% yield, Fig. 5C). Further elucidation of the structure was performed by GC-MS (Fig. S3) and NMR spectroscopy, which revealed the presence of diastereoisomers in a 1:1 ratio (Fig. 6 A). The precise assignment of signals in the spectra of isolated exocyclic (R)-carvone epoxide isomers is described in the Supplementary Material (see Tables S1 and S2). These experimental results suggest that an alkyl group present of 1-methylimidazole improves the catalytic epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond when compared to imidazole. On the other hand, when a pyridine-type nitrogen atom is alkylated in the cooperating ligand (EMIzoleBF4), there is almost no formation of the exocyclic epoxide (only 2% maximum yield). These results reinforce the suggestion that only pyridine-type nitrogen favors the complex catalytic activity for the epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond. As shown in Fig. 5B, an ionic liquid EMIzoleBF4 led to 19% yield of the endocyclic epoxide after 5 h, which is slightly higher than the yield for the reaction in the absence of any ligand (14%). At the same time, imidazole and 1-methylimidazole totally inhibit the activity of the Ga-catalyzed system for the endocyclic epoxide formation, probably due to the neutralization of its acidic sites by a stronger (and more basic) pyridine-type nitrogen atom present in imidazole. When the Lewis basicity of such nitrogen is removed, with its pair of electrons reacting to form the imidazole salt (EMIzoleBF4), there is no longer inhibition on the activity of the Ga+3 for the endocyclic epoxidation. 3.1.5 Acidic cooperating ligands Taking into account the previous results, in which inhibition of endocyclic epoxide formation is much more prominent in pyridine-type nitrogen ligands without carboxylic acid group attached, we explored the influence of acidic cooperating ligands on the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone, namely pyrazine-2- carboxylic (PCA), picolinic acid, acetic, and nitric acid (Fig. 7 ). The addition of acidic ligands favors the selective epoxidation of the endocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (Fig. 7B). In the absence of ligands, the conversion of 65% was observed after 3 h of reaction. The highest conversion (95%) was obtained using PCA ligand, followed by conversions bellow 75% for the other acidic ligands (Fig. 7A. The highest yield of the endocyclic epoxide (22% after 1 h) was obtained with acetic acid (pKa = 4.76) [30], followed by nitric acid (18%, the only inorganic acid tested; pKa < 1)[30] and the ligand-free system (15% yield). The pKa of the aqua gallium complex formed in the system is 2.6 [31]. According to Novikov et al. [20], this complex can be a promising catalyst for the epoxidation of α,β-unsaturated ketones. As cooperating ligands, PCA (pKa = 2.92) [32] and picolinic acid (pKa = 5,4) [33] showed similar results at the beginning of the reaction, both leading to a 10% yield of the endocyclic epoxide after 30 min. The reactions with PCA and acetic acid resulted in a decomposition of the endocyclic epoxide after a certain period (Fig. 7A). PCA was the only acid that improved the epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond in (R)-carvone (Fig. 7C). Kirillov and Shul'pin [34] described PCA as the most powerful co-catalyst for various oxidation reactions. In the present study, PCA can be an important tool to control the selectivity in the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone. For example, if the desired product is the exocyclic epoxide, the yield of this epoxide reaches a maximum of 25% after 3 h. On the other hand, if the endocyclic epoxide is the desired product, acetic acid can be used as a cooperating ligand, resulting in a 22% epoxide yield after 1 h (Fig. 7B). In view of this promising behavior of PCA in combination with Ga(NO3)3/H2O2, we selected this system as a model to perform kinetic studies on the epoxidation (R)-carvone. 3.2 Kinetic study of (R)-carvone epoxidation To unveil some kinetic features in the epoxidation of (R)-carvone with the Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 system, the reaction rates at different variables such as the concentration of substrate, catalyst, ligand, and oxidant were investigated (Fig. 8 ). According to Fig. 8A, the initial rate of the endocyclic epoxide formation is higher than that of the exocyclic epoxide. At the same time, the rate of the endocyclic epoxide formation is close to the value of the initial rate of (R)-carvone consumption (Fig. 7A). As evidenced by the data of Fig. 7, as the reaction proceeds, the total yield of epoxides is noticeably lower than the consumption of carvone. In addition, the mass balance decreases as the reaction proceeds, indicating subsequent oxidation of the formed epoxides to unidentified products (overoxidation). An alternative explanation is the action of indiscriminate oxidizing species that also enable the oxidation of carvone that may compete with epoxidation reaction. However, the initial rates of carvone consumption and formation of epoxides are close, at least in the system containing PCA. According to the data of Fig. 8E, the activation energies of the epoxidation processes leading to both types of epoxides are close and within 7–8 kcal/mol. This indicates that the epoxide formation is induced by the same type of oxidizing species generated in Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 system. This assumption is also consistent with the identity of the dependencies of the initial reaction rates for the formation of both epoxides on the concentrations of (R)-carvone, PCA, and hydrogen peroxide (Fig. 8). In our opinion, a low value of the observed activation energy for the generation of oxidizing species is not typical for the reactions that entirely rely on the hydroxyl radicals generated via thermal and/or catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. Furthermore, an assumption about the decisive role of free hydroxyl radicals in the epoxidation of (R)-carvone is not consistent with the fact that ligands influence the selectivity of epoxidation (the ratio of endocyclic and exocyclic epoxides). In this regard, we concluded that the dominant process in the (R)-carvone epoxidation is induced by Ga-peroxo complexes, even though some amount of hydroxyl radicals might be present in the reaction systems. Consequently, the effect of ligands on selectivity could be associated with the spatial and electronic features (availability of the reaction center epoxidizing double bonds in (R)-carvone), and the reactivity and stability of the resulting peroxo complexes. 3.3 EPR study of catalytic systems The epoxidation of (R)-carvone by the Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 system was further monitored for the formation of HO· and HOO· radicals by EPR spectroscopy (Fig. 9 ). After 15 min of the reaction, the DMPO/·OH EPR spectrum showed a characteristic quartet 1:2:2:1 indicating the presence of hydroxyl radicals [35]. However, the highest concentration of HO· was identified by the corresponding radical adduct signal after 15 min. At the same time, a lower signal was observed in the spectrum referring to DMPO/·OOH, suggesting that there is a small amount of HOO·. The following spectra show a remarkable decomposition of both radical adducts. It should be noted that the spectra of the blank experiment at 0 min showed no radicals in the reaction medium in the absence of catalyst (Fig. 9). The concentration of radical adducts DMPO/·OH + DMPO/·OOH during the epoxidation of (R)-carvone in the Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 catalytic system is listed in Table 2 . The highest concentration of radical adducts (6620 μM) is observed in the first 15 min, which then decreases to 1670 μM at 60 min, with a consequent increase in the exocyclic epoxide yield. This relationship could indicate that the consumption of radicals is associated with the formation of the exocyclic epoxide, since HO· radicals present high electrophilicity and lead to the oxidation of species with higher electron density [36]. The same temporal evolution of radical adducts was monitored for the catalytic Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 system in the absence of cooperating ligands (Fig. 10 ). The characteristic signals of radical adducts present a significantly lower intensity (Table 3 ) if compared with the system containing PCA. The intensity of signals increases from 680 μM at 15 min to 820 μM at 30 min, proportionally to the yields of the endocyclic epoxide, 13 and 15%, respectively (Table 3). Thus, a radical pathway is not responsible for the formation of endocyclic epoxide by the catalytic system. Considering the data discussed in Section 3.2, we believe that hydroxyl radicals, even though they appear in the system, do not determine the observed rate of exocyclic epoxide formation. Apparently, the rate of radical formation is low. The observed epoxidation rate is eventually determined by the interaction of the Ga-peroxo complex with (R)-carvone, similar to the non-radical pathway proposed by Novikov et al. [20]. 3.4 H2O2 efficiency in epoxidation of (R)-carvone The highest H2O2 efficiency, 95%, was observed for the epoxidation of (R)-carvone in the absence of a catalyst. This result can be justified by a less intense catalase reaction (Fig. S4), low substrate conversion (32%) and total yield of 8% after 5 h (Table 4 ). Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 catalytic system also showed high H2O2 efficiency, namely 90 and 80% after 3 and 5 h, respectively. The reduction of H2O2 efficiency to 80% was probably due to the decomposition of quantified epoxides (from 18% at 3 h to 17% at 5 h). The Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 and Ga(NO3)3/Met-Imida/H2O2 catalytic systems revealed better yields of epoxides (25% and 32%, respectively, after 5 h). The system with 1-methylimidazole (Met-Imida) showed an increase in H2O2 efficiency from 75% (3 h) to 85% (5 h), associated with a better mass balance at the end of the reaction (78%). However, the system with PCA presented an inferior H2O2 efficiency (65%, 3 h), possibly associated with the decomposition of epoxides, mainly the endocyclic epoxide (Table 4). 4 Conclusions In the present work, we explored the Ga-catalyzed epoxidation of (R)-carvone, aiming at studying the role of different cooperating ligands on the formation of endocyclic and exocyclic epoxide products. The use of Ga(NO3)3 as a catalyst led to an improvement in the conversion and yield of the endocyclic epoxide (15%). The introduction of N-heterocyclic compounds as cooperating ligands permitted to increase the yields of exocyclic epoxide, especially when the ligands present no substituents or electron-donating groups, namely pyrazine (28% yield), 1-methylimidazole (43% yield) and 4-dimethylaminopyridine (28% yield). As cooperating ligands, simple acids such as nitric and acetic acid led to an increase in the yield of endocyclic epoxide (18% and 22%, respectively). As a cooperating ligand comprising N-heterocycle ring and carboxylic acid functionality, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid (PCA) was particularly efficient for producing the exocyclic epoxide (25% yield). The influence of various reaction parameters was investigated, including kinetic, EPR, and oxidant efficiency studies. The dominant epoxidation process is the interaction of Ga-peroxo complexes with (R)-carvone. Although hydroxyl radicals are evolving during the decomposition of Н2О2, these do not make a significant contribution to the observed epoxidation processes, since the rate of their generation is low in comparison to the rate of epoxidation with Ga-peroxo complexes. The scientific results presented in this work can be applied to the following topics: (a) experimental and computational studies to explain the mechanism and differences among activity and selectivity in the alkene epoxidation reactions, including substrates with poor electron double bonds; (b) synthesis and isolation of new complexes of Ga with different application [37,38]; (c) new heterogeneous catalysts for alkene epoxidation based on gallium(III) metal-organic frameworks and organic linkers with N-donor cooperating ligands [39,40]. In summary, the obtained herein results show that different Ga(NO3)3/ligand/H2O2 systems can be used in the epoxidation of (R)-carvone to tune the selectivity toward the formation of endocyclic and exocyclic epoxides. Despite the overall selectivity of the studied epoxidation reactions is still modest, we believe this work opens up a possibility of applying a concept of cooperating ligands in molecular catalysis toward further development of more efficient epoxidation reactions catalyzed by non-transition metal centers. Future research on extending the family of possible cooperating ligands, widening the substrate scope to other terpene substrates, and improving the overall efficiency of the present type of catalytic transformations is currently in progress in our laboratories. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the catalytic epoxidation of (R)-carvone by the Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 system was studied alongside the metal-ligand cooperation by exploring 17 different ligands. It was observed that the acidic ligands such as acetic acid mostly favor the epoxidation of the endocyclic double bond of (R)-carvone (22% yield, 1 h), while nitrogen heterocycles direct the epoxidation to the exocyclic double bond, especially the ones that are unsubstituted or have electron-donating groups, such as pyrazine (28% yield, 5 h), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (28% yield, 8 h), and 1-methyimidazole (43% yield, 8 h). Pyrazinecaboxylic acid favored the epoxidation of the exocyclic double bond (25%, 3 h). EPR analysis of both Ga(NO3)3/H2O2 and Ga(NO3)3/PCA/H2O2 systems indicates the presence of hydroxyl radicals in the reaction medium, although these do not determine the epoxidation rate that is likely regulated by the interaction of Ga-peroxo complexes with (R)-carvone. This study contributes to widening the application of the cooperating ligand concept in molecular catalysis toward further development of more selective and efficient epoxidation reactions catalyzed by non-transition metal centers.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-ligand cooperation in the catalytic oxidation of (R)-carvone by Ga(NO3)3/H2O2
